[214166/1]   
OAH No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC No. E -015/PA -24-198 
 
STATE OF MINNESOTA  
OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS  
 
FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
and Global Infrastructure Partners  EXHIBIT A  
PROTECTIVE ORDER FOR HIGHLY 
CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET DATA  
By my signature below, I acknowledge that I have read the attached Protective 
Order for Highly Confidential Trade Secret Data dated December 5 , 2024  in Minnesota 
Public Utilities Commission Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 and OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -
40339 , and understand and agree to be bound by all of its terms.  
Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, I agree not to disclose to any person 
or entity not authorized to receive materials designated “HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL 
TRADE SECRET INFORMATION”  under the terms of the Protective Order for Highly 
Confidential Trade Secret Data, or any copies or extracts of information derived 
therefrom, which have been disclosed to me. I further agree to use any materials 
disclosed to me solely for the purpose of t his proceeding and for no other purpose.  
I submit myself to the jurisdiction of the Minnesota Office of Administrative 
Hearings and the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission for the purpose of enforcing the 
Protective Order for Highly Confidential Trade Secret Data.

Lebens Direct  I. BACKGROUND AND QUALIFICATIONS  1 
Q. Please state your name and business address.  2 
A. My name is Brian Lebens.  My business address is Suite 600, 445 Minnesota Street, Saint 3 
Paul, Minnesota 55101. 4 
Q. By whom are you employed? 5 
A. I am a Financial Analyst with the Office of the Minnesota Attorney General – Residential 6 
Utilities Division (OAG).   7 
Q. What are the Attorney General’s responsibilities regarding utility consumers?  8 
A. Among other things, “ the attorney general is responsible for  representing and furthering 9 
the interests of residential and small business utility consumers through participation in 10 
matters before the Public Utilities Commission involving utility rates and adequacy of 11 
utility services to residential or small business utility consumers .”1 12 
Q. What is your educational and professional background?  13 
A. I hold an MBA from the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota as 14 
well as a bachelor of science degree in f inance, also from the Carlson School.  I have eight 15 
years of experience in finance with 3M Company and Lockheed Martin.  My 16 
responsibilities at these firms  included financial modeling, cost accounting, audit, 17 
discounted cash flow analysis, and project management including cost and schedule 18 
analysis.  I also provided strategic financial counsel to senior leadership in the areas for 19 
which I was responsible.   20 
I started with the OAG in 2015, and I have provided testimony on behalf of the 21 
OAG before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (Commission) in seven electric 22 
1 Minn. Stat. § 8.33, subd. 2. 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT- 
NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
2           D ock et No s.  E-015/PA-24-198, M-24-383 
Lebens Direct  rate cases and eight natural gas rate cases.  I also testified in the Commission’s inquiry into 1 
natural gas utilities’ actions during Winter Storm Uri in February 2021, where I described 2 
utilities’ failure to hedge customer exposure to the financial impact of spikes in the market 3 
price of natural gas.  More recently, I provided testimony as part of an inquiry into service - 4 
quality violations by a wireline telecommunications carrier.  5 
II. TESTIMONY OVERVIEW  6 
Q. What is the purpose of your testimony? 7 
A. The purpose of my testimony is to provide the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission 8 
(“Commission”) information to help it decide whether to approve the proposed acquisition 9 
of ALLETE, Inc. by a small number of private investors. 10 
Q. What do  you discuss in your testimony? 11 
A. First, I provide an overview of the proposed acquisition , including describing the investors 12 
who are proposing to acquire ALLETE.  Then I provide a high- level introduction to the 13 
“private equity”  business.  Next,  I explain  that the Partners’ past actions provide indications 14 
of both potential benefits and risks to Minnesota P ower if the proposed acquisition were 15 
approved.  Finally, I explain several potential steps that Minnesota Power  and ALLETE  16 
could take toward reaching the State of Minnesota’s clean energy goals if the Commission 17 
does not approve the proposed acquisition in its current form.  At this time, I do not provide 18 
an overall recommendation on whether the Commission should approve or not approve the 19 
proposed acquisition, but I do request that ALLETE and the Partners propose additional 20 
conditions that would (1) enhance the probability that the potential benefits materialize  and 21 
(2)help mitigate the risks . 22 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT- 
NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
3           D o cket No s.  E-015/PA-24-198, M-24-383 
Lebens Direct  Q. At a high level, h ow could the acquisition impact Minnesotans if it is approved?  1 
A. The proposed transaction has the potential to i mpact a wide variety of areas, including jobs, 2 
infrastructure investment, electricity prices, electricity bills , and the broader community.  3 
Additionally, Minnesotans would no longer be able to purchase ALLETE shares on the 4 
New York Stock Exchange and therefore would not be able to do things like directly vote 5 
for the members of the board of directors.   6 
III. THE PROPOSED TRANSACTION 7 
Q. Please describe ALLETE, Inc.  8 
A. ALLETE is a diversified publicly traded  firm headquartered in Duluth, Minnesota .  9 
ALLETE has several wholly owned subsidiaries operating a variety of businesses. 10 
Minnesota Power is an electric utility that is currently an operating division of ALLETE, 11 
rather than one of its wholly owned subsidiaries.   12 
Minnesota Power has  an exclusive service territory in which everyone wishing to 13 
connect to the electric grid must do so through Minnesota Power.  Additionally, Minnesota 14 
Power operates under the jurisdiction of the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission in 15 
providing retail electric service .    In addition to Minnesota Power, ALLETE also holds 16 
several other investments such as : a coal mine, Florida real estate, solar/wind 17 
developers/operators, and eight percent of another company called American Transmission 18 
Company, LLC.  ATC is under the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ’s jurisdiction . 19 
Q. Can you briefly summarize the proposed acquisition?  20 
A. A group of investors is proposing to acquire ALLETE, Inc. and take it private.  This means, 21 
among many other things, that investors would no longer be able to buy shares of ALLETE 22 
(ticker symbol: ALE) on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE).  Existing ALLETE 23 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT- 
NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
      4           D ocket No s.  E-015/PA-24-198, M-24-383 
Lebens Direct  
 shareholders would receive $67 per share in cash, and, to the extent they are not a part of 1 
the group buying ALLETE, would no longer have shareholder rights.   2 
Overall, the proposed acquisition totals approximately $6.2 billion, which is 3 
comprised of approximately $3.9 billion of equity and “$2.3 billion of assumed ALLETE 4 
debt.”2  Part of the purchase price will be funded through new debt secured by the 5 
acquirers’ shares of ALLETE.  If the acquisition is approved as proposed, a newly formed 6 
limited liability company (LLC)  named Alloy Parent LLC would become the new direct 7 
owner of ALLETE, Inc. with a number of entities , including both LLCs and limited 8 
partnerships, existing in the corporate hierarchy above Alloy Parent  LLC .  The top of the 9 
hierarchy controlling ALLETE would be BlackRock, Inc. (ticker symbol: BLK).  10 
BlackRock has 15,000 employees in 38 countries and manages over $10 trillion in assets.   11 
Q. How is the $3.9 billion in equity calculated?  12 
A. The approximate $3.9 billion in equity is calculated by multiplying the number of 13 
outstanding shares by the $67 per share that the buyers are willing to pay. There are 14 
approximately 57.8 million ALLETE shares outstanding.3  So, 57.8 million shares at $67 15 
each equals approximately $3.9 billion. 16 
Q. Who are the investors that are trying to take ALLETE private? 17 
A. Entities controlled or managed by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and  18 
Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP) , including Tower Bridge Infrastructure Partners, L.P., 19 
are trying to take ALLETE private.  I will refer to CPP, GIP, and Tower Bridge as the 20 
Partners.  21 
 
2 Petition  for Approval at 10 and attach.  B, Article II Section 2.01(a) (July 19, 2024).

 Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP) is the trading name for Global Infrastructure  1 
Management, LLC, a private equity firm that provides investment management  services 2 
and advice to various GIP funds, “which hold, indirectly, investments  in portfolio 3 
companies.”4  GIP has raised several funds and its fifth fund, GIP Fund V, would hold 4 
GIP’s share of  ALLETE.   GIP was recently acquired by BlackRock, Inc.  in a deal valued 5 
at approximately $12.5 billion.5 6 
Tower Bridge Infrastructure Partners, L.P. is “a separately managed account 7 
(“SMA”) managed by GIP on behalf of the California Public Employees’ Retirement 8 
System (“CalPERS”).”6  “GIP will provide investment advice and management services to 9 
Tower Bridge just as it does with GIP Fund V.”7  GIP is compensated for the services it 10 
provides to Tower Bridge.8 11 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP) is an organization that manages 12 
Canada Pension Plan funds in the interest of 22 million participating Canadian contributors 13 
and beneficiaries.  CPP’s goals relate to, among other things, the financial security and 14 
income support of working Canadians.  CPP seeks to achieve its goals by, among other 15 
things, “maximizing returns without undue risk of loss.”9 16

 Q. Can you provide more detail on the proposed ownership structure of ALLETE post - 1 
transaction? 2 
A. Yes.  Through multiple layers of legal entities, CPP proposes to own 40 percent  of 3 
ALLETE.10  The remaining 60 percent  will be indirectly controlled by BlackRock through 4 
two funds: GIP Fund V and Tower Bridge Infrastructure Partners, L.P.  It is proposed that 5 
GIP Fund V own 40 percent  of ALLETE and that Tower Bridge own the remaining 20 6 
percent  of ALLETE.  7 
As I said earlier, the proposal includes several limited partnerships (LPs) and LLCs, 8 
some of which are illustrated in the Petition, as follows: 9 
 10

 Q. What are the entities through which GIP  is raising  capital for GIP Fund V? 1 
A. GIP lists the following entities in the Petition:  2 
1. Global Infrastructure Partners V -A/B, L.P.,  3 
2. Global Infrastructure Partners V -C Intermediate, L.P., and  4 
3. Global Infrastructure Partners V -C2 Intermediate, L.P.11 5 
Below, I refer to such entities as GIP’s “intermediate entities.”  6 
Q. What does it mean for GIP to control Tower Bridge’s interest?  7 
A. It means that GIP will be able to do things like vote on Tower Bridge’s behalf for the board 8 
of directors.  9 
Q. Were you able to find additional information about GIP’s intermediate entities?  10 
A. Yes.  Global Infrastructure Partners V -C2, L.P. lists the country of Luxembourg as its 11 
jurisdiction of incorporation/organization and, as of early 2024, had raised over $1.8 billion 12 
from 66 investors.12  13 
Additionally, the following three partnerships all list the Cayman Islands as their 14 
jurisdiction of incorporation/organization and, as of early  2024, had raised  over $8 billion 15 
from fewer than 100 investors through these Cayman Islands entities:   16 
1. Global Infrastructure Partners V -B Feeder Fund, L.P.,13  17

Q. Would ALLETE or Minnesota Power incur additional debt in connection with the 3 
acquisition?  4 
A. The Petition suggests that “ALLETE and Minnesota Power will not incur any additional 5 
debt in connection with the Acquisition” and notes that “[a] small portion of existing 6 
Company debt will be refinanced under the terms of the Merger Agreement, which will not 7 
affect costs to the regulated utility as described in Section IV.C.2 of the Petition.”  But 8 
ALLETE, GIP, and CPP all explain that Alloy Parent LLC has received commitments for 9 
a $600 million term loan and $100 million of revolving credit.16   10 
Q. What have been the recent developments regarding GIP’s ownership?  11 
A. In January 2024, GIP and BlackRock announced that they had entered into an agreement 12 
for BlackRock to acquire GIP for $3 billion in cash plus approximately 12 million 13 
BlackRock shares.17  As of late January 2025, BlackRock shares are trading for over $1,000 14 
each.18  In October 2024, GIP and BlackRock announced the acquisition’s successful 15 
 
14 See Global Infra . Partners V -C, L.P., Amended Notice of Exempt Offering of Securities 
(Mar.  26, 2024),

(Sept. 5, 2024), https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/2025003/000202500324000002/xslFormDX01/primar
y_doc.xml  (disclosing zero funds raised from zero investors as of that filing). 
16 See Anderson Direct at 18–19; Alley Direct at 24 ; Bram Direct at 27 –28.

Lebens Direct  
 completion and explained that “[t]he combination creates an industry leader in 1 
infrastructure across equity, debt and solutions.”19 2 
Q. Who would control ALLETE if the transaction is approved?  3 
A. Global Infrastructure Partners would maintain strategic control of both GIP Fund V’s 40  4 
percent interest and Tower Bridge’s 20 percent interest, ultimately reaching a 60  percent 5 
controlling share for GIP, now a wholly owned subsidiary of BlackRock.   Ultimate 6 
strategic control rests with BlackRock for all of the subsidiaries in which it has a controlling 7 
interest within its corporate hierarchy .  BlackRock itself is not necessarily involved with 8 
the “day -to-day” activities of its subsidiaries.20 9 
IV. INTRODUCTION TO PRIVATE EQUITY. 10 
Q. You’ve described GIP as a “private equity” firm.  What is “private equity?” 11 
A. Private equity has been described as follows:  12 
The term private equity investment  in the most general sense means 13 
investments in equity (stock) of companies that are not traded on stock 14 
exchanges and, therefore, are not available for investment by the general 15 
public.  Private equity firms  are financial intermediaries that help investors 16 
(usually large institutional investors and often referred to as limited partners 17 
or “LP’s”) make private equity investments by contributing capital to 18 
“funds” established by the private equity firms.  Successful private equity 19 
investing relies on careful evaluation of investments , structuring the 20 
investments or deals , financial engineering and operational engineering.21 21 
 
19 Press Release, BlackRock, BlackRock Completes Acquisition of Global Infrastructure Partners 
(Oct. 1, 2024) , attached as Schedule BPL -D-2. 
20 Day-to-day activities could include working within established budgets for things like routine 
entry -level  recruiting, onboarding, and scheduling; coordinating with vendors to purchase office 
supplies; or community engagement. 
21 PAUL ALAN GOMPERS & STEVEN N. KAPLAN , ADVANCED INTRODUCTION TO PRIVATE EQUITY  
11 (eBook ed. 2022) (emphases in original). 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT- 
NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
      10           D ocket No s.  E-015/PA-24-198, M-24-383 
Lebens Direct  
 Q. Would you explain the structure of private equity firms and private equity funds?  1 
A. Yes.  Private equity firms are often started and run by people with finance, consulting, or 2 
business operations backgrounds.  Many private -equity- firm founders and employees hold 3 
an MBA or are former CEOs.  Private equity funds often comprise l imited partners and a 4 
general partner .  Limited partners (LPs) commit to provide most of the capital for the fund’s 5 
eventual investments.  The general partner (GP) is owned, controlled, or managed by one 6 
or more employees of a private equity firm.  The GP selects the fund’s investments and 7 
may provide a limited amount of capital to the fund.  For example, a  GP may provide 8 
2 percent of a fund’s capital while the LPs may provide the remaining 98 percent .  The GP 9 
works to gain investment commitments from potential LPs.  The LPs do not generally 10 
provide all of the cash to the GP immediately; the GP receives “commitments from LPs 11 
rather than actual cash.”22  The LPs provide cash to the GP only when the GP needs it for 12 
an investment or to pay fees; Gompers and Kaplan refer to this as “‘just in time’ funding 13 
of investments and fees.”23  14

A. LPs are often institutional investors like sovereign wealth funds  and pension funds, or high- 19 
net-worth individual people.   20

 Q. Would you explain the fee structures of private equity firms in general?  1 
A. Yes.  A classic fee structure used by private equity, hedge funds, and venture capital firms 2 
is the “ 2 and 20 ” model, immortalized in the title of a book by Sachin Khajuria —Two and 3 
Twenty: How the Masters of Private Equity Always Win.  The “2” references a fee equal 4 
to 2 percent of an investor’s assets and the “20” references 20 percent of profits.  That 5 
means that for each $100 an investor invests, the firm will retain its $2 asset fee plus $2 of 6 
a $10 annual profit, so the investment firm would earn fees of $4 and, after fees , the investor 7 
would end the year with $106.  There could be other variations on the 2 and 20 model such 8 
as splitting profits 50/50 instead of 80/20. 9 
Q. What is “public equity” as distinct from private equity?  10 
A. The main  distinction is  whether or not a company’s shares are traded on a public exchange 11 
like the New York Stock Exchange.  Companies with shares that are publicly traded are 12 
also known as public companies.24  Investors in public companies are also  referred to as 13 
“public equity investors ,” and the markets in which public companies trade are called 14 
public equity markets.   15 
Q. How do private equity investors differ from public equity investors?  16 
A.  As I noted earlier, private equity investors are often institutional investors like , sovereign 17 
wealth funds  and pension funds, or high- net-worth individual people.  Public investors can 18 
be almost anyone, including individuals, investment firms , or pension funds. 19

companies.  5 
 Q. Do most companies start out as private companies? 6 
A. Yes, most companies start out private and remain private.  There are millions of private 7 
companies in the United States25 and currently fewer than  5,000 public companies.26   8

A. No, most private firms are not private equity firms that raise investment commitments from 11

only one employee like carpenters, or electricians.   13

 Q. Why would a private company want to become a public company? 1 
A. There could be many reasons that a private company might want to go public.  The U.S. 2 
Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) lists several reasons, the first of which is “to 3 
raise capital and potentially broaden opportunities for future access to capital.”27 4 
Q. When was ALLETE first listed on the NYSE?  5 
A. ALLETE’s predecessor, Minnesota Power and Light, was first listed on the NYSE in 1950, 6 
allowing it to access capital to build power plants in “the 1950s through the 1970s to help 7 
accommodate an increasing industrial load.”28 8 
Q. Why would a company that has already gone public want to revert to being a private 9 
company? 10 
A. There could be many  reasons that a public company may want to go private, including the 11 
ability to  shift strategies  more easily  or avoiding things that public companies face like 12 
activist shareholders.  Reducing dividend payments  would also be easier  as a private 13 
company. 14 
Q. How do private equity investment strategies differ from those of public investors?  15 
A. Most investors pursue financial profit goals.  However, many of the strategies that  private 16 
equity firms use to achieve those profit goals significantly differ from the strategies of other 17 
types of investors, including investors in public companies.   18

 Investors in public companies generally do not seek to make significant changes to 1 
the businesses in which they invest,29 while private equity firms often seek to become the 2 
controlling shareholder in order to make significant changes, including: 3 
1. Changes to the board of directors,  4 
2. Changes to strategy, 5 
3. Changes to the lines of business in which the company operates,  6 
4. Changes to the level of day- to-day operating expenses,  7 
5. Changes to long- term capital expenses, or  8 
6. Changes to the capital structure of the business. 9 
Changes like those often serve to  change a business ’ cash flow.  10 
Q. What is cash flow?  11 
A. Cash flow is the net amount of cash going into or out of an organization during a given 12 
time frame like a fiscal year.   13 
Q. H ow might a private equity firm change cash flow? 14 
A. Increasing sales and cutting costs are classic examples that would generally improve cash 15 
flow.  Taking on additional debt (adding leverage) and selling assets can bring cash into a 16 
business in a given year.  Additionally, paying suppliers more slowly or asking customers 17 
to pay earlier  could improve cash flow.  18 
Q. How else do investment strategies differ between public and private equity investors?  19 
A. Public and private  equity investors have significantly different exit strategies. An “exit 20 
strategy” is a plan for eventually ending involvement with a particular investment; it may 21 
include specific timing , methods, and  objectives, or it may be a more generalized plan.    22 
 
29 However , some investors in public companies specifically pursue activist -investor strategies that 
benefit from taking control of a target company.

 The exit strategy for investors in public companies is often simply selling their 1 
shares through the same public market where they originally purchased the shares at a time 2 
when they feel the shares are fully valued.  3 
Private equity exit strategies are often much more specific regarding timing; many 4 
private equity funds have a pre -planned lifespan, after which the GP will sell the fund’s 5 
investments with the goal of maximizing profit for the LPs.  Private equity exit strategies 6 
can include (1) strategic buyers, (2) financial buyers, or (3) an initial public offering (IPO) 7 
into public markets.  Analyzing the type of buyer for an eventual exit strategy is  an 8 
important consideration for private equity firms.   9 
Q. Can you please define the three types of private equity exits you mentioned above? 10 
A. “Strategic buyer” refers to a buyer that would likely  integrate the new acquisition into its 11 
existing operations .  A “financial buyer” could be an entity  like another private equity fund 12 
or a hedge fund.30  An IPO refers to allowing the public to trade the shares of a company 13 
by listing them on a public stock exchange, like the NYSE.  A private equity firm could 14 
pursue an IPO for the entire firm as a whole or for one or more of the companies it owns, 15 
individually or as a n amalgamated  group.   16 
Q. After an IPO, does a  public company continue to buy and sell its shares back and 17 
forth with public  investors ? 18 
A. G enerally,  no.  Public i nvestors primarily buy and sell shares among themselves.  If the 19 
listed company has excess cash or thinks its shares are underpriced, however, it may buy  20 
back  some shares; conversely, if the listed company needs additional capital , it may sell 21 
 
30 One type of financial buyer is a continuation fund which refers to a new fund established by a 
private equity firm that would buy an asset from one of the firm’s existing funds.

party investors, and  the listed company is not generally involved with these transactions.  2

Q. Are there any other differences between private equity investors and public 8 
shareholders?  9 
A. Private equity firms may strategically increase the amount of debt, or “ leverage, ” being 10 
used within a business or within the corporate hierarchy above it in order to increase their 11 
potential profit percentage.   The  private equity firm may do this  through its control of the 12 
board of directors. 13

 Q. How can increasing the amount of debt used to finance a business lead to higher 1 
returns on equity?  2 
A. Using a lower amount of equity (and a corresponding higher amount of debt) amplifies or 3 
“leverages ” the returns.  Leverage amplifies both positive and negative returns.  I will 4 
provide a simple example of leverage amplifying a positive return:  Think about buying a 5 
house for $100,000 in cash (no debt) and immediately  selling it for $120,000.  That would 6 
provide a 20 percent  return.31  Compare that with a second scenario where the house is still 7 
purchased for $100,000 and sold right away for $120,000 but the purchase is funded using 8 
a $50,000 loan and $50,000 of the buyer’s own  cash.  In that scenario, the return for the 9 
buyer would double from 20 percent  to 40 percent32 because the buyer is using less of their 10 
own cash to achieve the same $20,000 profit. 11 
Q. What are some of the other potential impacts of leverage on a company? 12 
A. It has been said that “the large, fixed interest and principal repayment schedules on debt 13 
enforce [s] discipline.”33  In other words, additional debt in an organization’s capital 14 
structure puts pressure on management to avoid incurring unnecessary expenses. 15 
  Increased debt weakens certain credit metrics and can weaken a company’s credit 16 
rating. 17 
  Excessive debt levels can erode shareholder value  if the debt causes profit to decline 18 
too much.  Relatedly , a company that avoids low -cost debt may erode shareholder value .  19 
 
31 20% = $20,000 / $100,000 
32 40% = $20,000 / $50,000

 That is, both excessive and insufficient debt  can result in a suboptimal capital structure  1 
with an unnecessarily high cost of capital.34 2 
Finally, in extreme cases when a company is unable to repay its debts, liquidation 3 
or reorganization through the bankruptcy process can result. 4 
Q. What might a private equity firm’s investment strategy look like for a n electric  5 
utility?  6 
A. M ost, if not all, of the private equity strategies, including those  I discuss above , could apply 7 
to a privately owned utility.  P rivate equity  strategies for a utility could include things like 8 
working to increase sales, cutting labor or other expenses, adding leverage, and generally 9 
exercising strategic control through the ability to select the board of directors.  A private 10 
equity firm could also use the utility’s monopoly position to maximize the profitability  of 11 
the firm’s broader investment portfolio by influencing the business decisions of affiliated 12 
companies.   Overlapping board memberships between the utility and  its parent entities 13 
could directly or indirectly support those efforts.35 14

 VII. CONCLUSION 1 
Q. What do you conclude?  2 
A. I conclude that the proposed acquisition holds risks, uncertainties, and potential benefits  3 
for Minnesota Power and its ratepayers .  The Commission should carefully weigh the risks 4 
and uncertainties against the potential benefits as it decides whether to approve the 5 
proposed acquisition of ALLETE and the resulting  transfer of control from public investors 6 
to a consortium of private equity investors, with a 60 percent stake controlled by the largest 7 
asset manager in the world, BlackRock, Inc. 8 
Q. Do you have any further requests?  9 
A. I request that, in their rebuttal testimony, ALLETE and the Partners propose conditions 10 
that would mitigate the potential harms  and help ensure the potential benefits of the 11 
proposed transaction materialize if it is approved.  Specifically, proposed conditions 12 
should, at minimum,  address : 13 
1. Potential b enefits : 14 
a. The Partners’  expertise in things like continuous improvement and 15 
operational efficiency  could help mitigate  Minnesota Power’s rate 16 
increases .  17 
b. The Partners ’ expertise in  optimiz ing the capital structure , the cost of 18 
capital, and cash flow  could help mitigate Minnesota Power’s rate 19 
increases.  20 
2. Potential harms : 21 
a. The risk that board of director control could be abused. 22 
b. The risk that the Partners could decide to reallocate needed capital away 23 
from Minnesota Power. 24 
c. The risk that the Partners could over -allocate capital to Minnesota 25 
Power’s rate base that is not needed for the energy transition. 26

BlackRock Agrees to Acquire Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”), Creating a World Leading
Infrastructure Private Markets Investment Platform
- GIP is the world’s largest independent infrastructure manager with over $100 billion in AUM and a strong reputation for driving
operational improvements in its portfolio companies & proprietary origination
- Transaction creates a market-leading, multi-asset class infrastructure investing platform with combined client AUM of over
$150 billion across equity, debt and solutions & strengthens deal ow and co-investment opportunities
- Transaction structured for leadership continuity and alignment with BlackRock’s stockholders, with substantial majority of total
consideration to be paid in BlackRock stock
- GIP’s management team will lead the combined, highly complementary infrastructure platform
NEW YORK--(BUSINESS WIRE)--BlackRock, Inc. (NYSE: BLK) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”), a leading independent
infrastructure fund manager, jointly announce that they have entered into an agreement for BlackRock to acquire GIP for total
consideration of $3 billion of cash and approximately 12 million shares of BlackRock common stock.
A $1 trillion market today, infrastructure is forecast to be one of the fastest growing segments of private markets in the years
ahead. A number of long-term structural trends support an acceleration in infrastructure investment. These include increasing
global demand for upgraded digital infrastructure like ber broadband, cell towers and data centers; renewed investment in
logistical hubs such as airports, railroads and shipping ports as supply chains are rewired; and a movement toward
decarbonization and energy security in many parts of the world.PRESS RELEASES

Further, large government decits mean that the mobilization of capital through public-private partnerships will be critical for
funding important infrastructure. Finally, as capital has become more scarce in a higher interest rate environment, companies
are exploring partnership opportunities for their embedded infrastructure assets to improve their returns on invested capital or
to raise capital to reinvest in their core businesses.BlackRock has a broad network of global corporate relationships as a long-term investor in both their debt and equity. These
relationships will help us lead critical investments in infrastructure to improve outcomes for communities around the globe and
generate long-term investment benets for clients.
The combination of GIP with BlackRock’s highly complementary infrastructure offerings creates a comprehensive global
infrastructure franchise with differentiated origination and asset management capabilities. The over $150 billion combined
business will seek to deliver clients market-leading, holistic infrastructure expertise across equity, debt and solutions at
substantial scale. Marrying the proprietary origination and business improvement capabilities of GIP and BlackRock’s global
corporate and sovereign relationships provides a platform for diversied, large-scale sourcing to support deal ow and co-
investment opportunities for clients. We believe bringing GIP and BlackRock together will deliver to clients the benets of
broader origination and business improvement capabilities.Founded in 2006, world leading independent infrastructure investor GIP manages over $100 billion in client assets across
infrastructure equity and debt, with a focus on energy, transport, water and waste, and digital sectors. GIP’s performance has
been driven by proprietary origination, operational improvements, and timely exits. They have successfully scaled their global
equity agship series, with the most recent fully invested agship fund in 2019 surpassing $22 billion.BlackRock’s over $50 billion of infrastructure client AUM is comprised of infrastructure equity, debt and solutions, and has grown
both organically and inorganically since inception in 2011. Top investment talent at BlackRock lead franchises that include
Diversied Infrastructure, Infra Debt, Infra Solutions, Climate Infrastructure and Decarbonization Partners.
The GIP management team, led by Bayo Ogunlesi and four of its founding partners, will lead the combined infrastructure
platform. They will bring with them talented investment, and operationally focused business improvement teams with a strong
track-record of building and running high-performing private markets businesses. GIP’s founders and teams remain highly
committed to clients, and we expect the integration with BlackRock’s broader platform will generate even greater opportunities.
Subject to completion of customary onboarding procedures, BlackRock has also agreed to appoint Bayo Ogunlesi, GIP Founding
Partner, Chairman and Chief Executive Ofcer, to the Board at the next regularly scheduled board meeting following the closing
of the transaction.“Infrastructure is one of the most exciting long-term investment opportunities, as a number of structural shifts re-shape the
global economy. We believe the expansion of both physical and digital infrastructure will continue to accelerate, as governments
prioritize self-sufciency and security through increased domestic industrial capacity, energy independence, and onshoring or
near-shoring of critical sectors. Policymakers are only just beginning to implement once-in-a-generation nancial incentives for
new infrastructure technologies and projects,” said Laurence D. Fink, BlackRock Chairman and CEO.“I’m delighted for the opportunity to welcome Bayo and the GIP team to BlackRock, and happy to announce our plans to have
Bayo join our Board of Directors post-closing. We founded BlackRock 35 years ago based on a unique understanding of
investment risk and the factors and forces driving investment returns. GIP’s deep understanding of the factors and forces driving
operational efciency for long-term value creation have made them a global leader in infrastructure investing. Bringing these
two rms together will create the infrastructure platform to deliver best-in-class investment opportunities for clients globally,
and we couldn’t be more excited about the opportunities ahead of us.”“I’m excited about the power of this combination and the prospect of working with Larry and his talented team. We share with
BlackRock a culture of collaboration, client focus, investment partnership, and commitment to excellence. Investors have
adopted private infrastructure investing for its ability to provide stable cashows, less correlated returns, and a hedge against
ination. Global corporates have turned to private infrastructure as a fast innovator and a more commercially agile owner of
infrastructure assets that aren't core to their commercial businesses. This platform is set to be the preeminent, one-stop
infrastructure solutions provider for global corporates and the public sector, mobilizing long-term private capital through long-
standing rm relationships,” said Bayo Ogunlesi, GIP Founding Partner, Chairman, and CEO. “We are convinced that together we
can create the world’s premier infrastructure investment rm.”GIP Prole1/30/25, 3:53 PM BlackRock Agrees to Acquire Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”)

GIP is the largest independent infrastructure manager by assets under management globally, with over $100 billion in AUM
across infrastructure equity and credit strategies supported by approximately 400 employees. Its over 40 portfolio companies
generate over $75 billion in annual revenue and employ approximately 115,000 people around the world. GIP’s success has been
driven by its targeted focus on real infrastructure assets in the transport, energy, digital, and water and waste sectors. GIP’s in-
depth knowledge of target industries underpins its ability to originate proprietary transactions through outright ownership and
corporate joint ventures, conduct deep and extensive diligence, and structure investments.In addition to proprietary origination, business improvement is a key pillar of GIP’s infrastructure approach, with a dedicated
team delivering deep operational enhancements. GIP has executed successful exits across multiple channels. Among GIP’s
investments are Gatwick, Edinburgh, and Sydney Airports, CyrusOne (data centers), Suez (water and waste), Pacic National and
Italo (rail), Peel Ports and Port of Melbourne, and several major renewables platforms, including Clearway, Vena, Atlas and Eolian.Terms of the Transaction
Under the terms of the transaction, BlackRock will acquire 100% of the business and assets of GIP for total consideration of $3
billion in cash and approximately 12 million shares of BlackRock common stock.
Approximately 30% of the total consideration, all in stock, will be deferred and is expected to be issued in approximately ve
years, subject to the satisfaction of certain post-closing events.
BlackRock intends to fund the cash consideration through $3 billion of additional debt. BlackRock is currently rated AA- with S&P
and Aa3 with Moody’s, and this transaction is not expected to meaningfully change its leverage prole. A securities rating is not a
recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision or withdrawal at any time.The deal is expected to be modestly accretive to BlackRock’s as-adjusted earnings per share and operating margin in the rst full
year post-close.
The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter of 2024 subject to customary regulatory approvals and other closing
conditions.
Perella Weinberg Partners served as lead nancial advisor to BlackRock, with Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom and Fried,
Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson LLP acting as legal counsel. Evercore served as lead nancial advisor and Kirkland & Ellis LLP
and Debevoise & Plimpton LLP acted as legal counsel to GIP.Conference Call Information
Executives from BlackRock and GIP will host a teleconference call for investors and analysts on Friday, January 12, 2024 at 7:30
a.m. (Eastern Time) to discuss the transaction, along with BlackRock’s results for the quarter and scal year ending December
31, 2023. Members of the public who are interested in participating in the teleconference should dial, from the United States,
(313) 209-4913, or from outside the United States, (866) 400-0049, shortly before 7:30 a.m. ET and reference the BlackRock
Conference Call (ID Number 3392098). A live, listen-only webcast will also be available via the investor relations section of
www.blackrock.com. A supplemental presentation on the transaction is available on the investor relations section of
www.blackrock.com.The webcast will be available for replay by 10:30 a.m. ET on Friday, January 12, 2024. To access the replay of the webcast, please
visit the investor relations section of www.blackrock.com .
About Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP)
Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP) is a leading infrastructure investor that specializes in investing in, owning and operating
some of the largest and most complex assets across the energy, transport, digital infrastructure and water and waste
management sectors. With decarbonization central to our investment thesis, we are well positioned to support the global energy
transition. Headquartered in New York, GIP has ofces in Brisbane, Dallas, Delhi, Hong Kong, London, Melbourne, Mumbai,
Singapore, Stamford and Sydney.GIP has over $100 billion in assets under management. Our portfolio companies have combined annual revenues of
approximately $75 billion and employ over 115,000 people. We believe that our focus on real infrastructure assets, combined1/30/25, 3:53 PM BlackRock Agrees to Acquire Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”)

NEW YORK – October 1, 2024 – BlackRock, Inc. (NYSE: BLK) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) announce the
successful completion of BlackRock’s acquisition of GIP. The combination creates an industry leader in infrastructure across
equity, debt and solutions – providing a diverse range of infrastructure sector expertise and exposure across developed and
emerging markets. The combined infrastructure platform will be branded Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), a part of
BlackRock. GIP will continue to be led by Bayo Ogunlesi and the Ofce of the Chairman. With approximately $170 billion in AUM,
the platform will eld a 600-person strong global team that manages a diversied portfolio of more than 300 active investments
with operations in over 100 countries. With this combination, BlackRock consolidates over $100 billion of private markets AUM,
and approximately $750 million of run rate management fees, boosting private markets AUM by approximately 40% and
expanding run rate revenues.“Infrastructure represents a generational investment opportunity. Through the combination of BlackRock and GIP, we are well
positioned to capitalize on the long-term structural trends that will continue to drive the growth of infrastructure and deliver
superior investment opportunities for clients globally,” said Laurence D. Fink, BlackRock Chairman and CEO. “We are thrilled to
welcome Bayo and the talented GIP team to BlackRock and look forward to providing our clients this combined depth and bench
of infrastructure investment expertise.”“We are excited to embark on this new chapter as Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), a part of BlackRock, with the goal of
creating the premier global infrastructure investing rm,” said Bayo Ogunlesi, Global Infrastructure Partners’ Chairman and
Chief Executive Ofcer. “The combination of our institutional intellectual capital, investing and business improvement
capabilities, global footprint, corporate and government relationships will allow us to deliver attractive investments for our
investors and innovative solutions for our customers.”BlackRock plans to appoint Bayo Ogunlesi to its Board of Directors at the next regularly scheduled Board meeting.
Perella Weinberg Partners served as lead nancial advisor to BlackRock, with Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom and Fried,
Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobsen LLP acting as legal counsel. Evercore served as lead nancial advisor and Kirkland & Ellis LLP
and Debevoise & Plimpton LLP acted as legal counsel to GIP.BlackRock Media Relations

Picking between private and public equity can play a key role in shaping
your portfolio strategy. Public equity offers easy access to market
information and the flexibility to quickly buy or sell shares. Private equity
investments, on the other hand, can involve more in-depth research and
due diligence, as they are typically less regulated and less transparent. Afinancial advisor  can work with you to analyze both types of investments
for your portfolio and help you manage the risks.
How Does Private Equity Work? 
Private equity  investment pools funds from high-net-worth individuals  and
institutional investors  to acquire stakes in private companies. Unlike public
markets, where shares are traded openly, private equity investments are
typically made in companies that are not listed on stock exchanges. 1/30/25, 3:56 PM Differences of Private vs. Public Equity | Nasdaq

The goal of a private equity investment is to improve the company’s value
over time through strategic management, operational improvements and
sometimes restructuring, before eventually selling the stake for a profit.
This process can take several years, during which the private equity firm
works closely with the company’s management to drive growth and
enhance profitability.
Private equity firms are responsible for raising capital, identifying potential
investment opportunities and managing the acquired companies. These
firms often supply expertise and other resources to help companies they
invest in reach growth targets. This assistance can involve anything from
providing strategic guidance to implementing cost-cutting measures or
expanding into new  markets. The ultimate aim is to exit the investment  at a
profit, typically through a sale or an initial public offering (IPO) .
Investing in private equity can offer higher returns but it also comes with
more risk. Private equity investments are generally illiquid, meaning they
cannot be easily sold or exchanged for cash. Additionally, success rests on
the ability of the private equity firm to effectively manage and grow  the
companies in their portfolio. Investors considering private equity must
conduct thorough due diligence and many work with a financial advisor to
help navigate the complexities.
How Does Public Equity Work? 
Public equity refers to shares of a company that are traded on public stock
exchanges, such as the New York Stock Exchange or NASDAQ. Companies
become public by offering shares to the general public through an initial
public offering (IPO). This process allows the company to tap a broad pool
of investors for capital to use for expansion, research and development or
other business needs.

For investors, public equity provides an opportunity to own a piece of a
company and potentially benefit from its growth and profitability. The value
of these shares fluctuates based on market conditions, company
performance and investor sentiment.
Public equity markets play an important role in the economy by facilitating
the flow of capital between investors and companies. These markets
provide liquidity, enabling investors to buy and sell shares with relative
ease. This liquidity is essential for maintaining investor confidence and
ensuring that companies can access the funds they need to grow. 
Public equity markets provide transparency because publicly traded
companies are required to disclose financial information regularly. This
helps investors make informed decisions and contributes to the stability
and efficiency of the financial system.
Investing in public equity can be an effective way to build wealth over time ,
but has its own risks as well. Share prices can be volatile, especially in the
short term, as they are affected by influences including economic
conditions, industry trends and geopolitical events. To mitigate  risk,
investors often diversify portfolios  by investing in a mix of stocks across
different sectors and regions. 1/30/25, 3:56 PM Differences of Private vs. Public Equity | Nasdaq

Each approach to equity investment has its own characteristics, risks and
opportunities. Here's a breakdown of seven key differences to consider
when investing in private or public equity.
Accessibility: Public equity is traded on stock exchanges, making it
easily accessible to individual investors. Private equity involves
investing in companies not listed on public exchanges, often requiring
significant capital as well as connections that can be hard to develop.Liquidity: Public equity offers high liquidity, as investors can buy and
sell shares quickly. Private equity investments are typically long-term,
with funds locked in for several years.
Regulation: Public companies are subject to strict regulatory
requirements and must disclose voluminous financial information.
Private companies have fewer regulatory obligations, so investors often
know less about what they are getting into.Transparency: The transparency of public equity can help investors
make more informed decisions based on available data.
Potential returns and risks: Private equity often targets higher returns,
but has higher risks due to less liquidity and transparency. Public
equity returns are generally more stable but can be influenced by
market volatility, especially in the short term.Investment horizon : Public equity investments can be short-term or
long-term, depending on market conditions and investor goals. Private
equity typically requires a long-term commitment, with a focus on value
creation over several years.1/30/25, 3:56 PM Differences of Private vs. Public Equity | Nasdaq

generally along for the ride.

History
Construction of the Bison Wind Energy Center in south-central North Dakota was completed in 2015.
Minnesota Power has its roots in a handful of electricity companies formed to provide power for a young
community, the timber industry and mining interests in the late 1800s and early 1900s in northeastern
Minnesota. As businesses thrived and the population grew in the mineral-rich and heavily forested area,
several utility companies consolidated and then incorporated in 1906 as Duluth Edison Electric Co., the
immediate predecessor of Minnesota Power.
In the early 1920s, six major electric utilities and many municipal and privately owned local plants were
operating in what is now Minnesota Power’s service territory. By 1923, after acquiring and consolidating
many regional utilities, the company became known as Minnesota Power and Light Co.
The stock of Minnesota Power and Light was first listed on the New York Stock Exchange in 1950 under the
ticker symbol MPL. When the corporate name was changed to ALLETE, Inc. in 2000, the stock’s ticker symbol
became ALE. Minnesota Power remains the largest division of ALLETE.
In the early days, the company relied on the region's rivers to generate hydropower to serve its customers. In
fact, the incorporation papers of the Duluth Edison Electric Co., read in part "to improve, develop and use
water power for heat, light and power purposes; and to develop, generate and use electric energy and
currents for heat, light and power purposes, otherwise than by water power."

Minnesota Power prospered during and after World War II with the expansion of iron ore mining,
forestry/paper industries, grain exports and shipbuilding on Lake Superior. Power plants, including Laskin
Energy Center, Taconite Harbor Energy Center and Boswell Energy Center, were built during the 1950s
through the 1970s to help accommodate an increasing industrial load.
Minnesota Power continues to generate energy at Boswell Energy Center Units 3 and 4 while adding more
sources of renewable energy. Today, Minnesota Power delivers 50% renewable energy to customers via its
hydro, solar, biomass and wind resources. The 25-megawatt Taconite Ridge Wind Center began operating in
2008, and the four-phase, 500-megawatt Bison Wind Energy Center in North Dakota was completed in 2015.
Laskin Energy Center was converted from coal to a natural gas peaking plant in 2015.1/30/25, 3:59 PM History - Minnesota Power is an ALLETE Company

Acquisition: (1) improved access to the capital necessary to fund Minnesota Power’s 3 
significant, planned investments in the coming years; and (2) access to the Partners’ 4 
expertise with respect to utility and energy infrastructure and renewables. Both of these 5 
benefits, however, appear highly speculative. First, the Petitioners have not provided 6 
meaningful evidence that the Company’s current access to capital is inadequate or that 7 
the Acquisition will improve its access to capital. In fact, as I discuss in greater detail 8

have not provided meaningful evidence that access to the Partners’ expertise will 11 
translate to material benefits to the Company or its ratepayers, such as lower rates 12 
resulting from operational cost cutting or improved procurement processes. Therefore, 13 
Acquisition should not be expected to provide any benefits to the public interest.  14

the Acquisition.  2 
A. I understand that Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (2024) governs acquiring property through 3 
merger and acquisition, and requires that the Commission find such transactions to be 4 
“consistent with the public interest” in order to authorize them. The Commission has 5 
previously found that this standard does not require an affirmative finding of benefits, 6 
just a finding that the transaction is compatible with the public interest.1 7 
  Th e Commission has historically used a balancing test to determine if an 8 
acquisition is “consistent with the public interest,” weighing perceived detriments 9 
against benefits. The Commission has recognized that evaluation of proposed 10 
transactions like the Acquisition must of necessity be somewhat speculative. No one 11 
knows with absolute certainty every effect a significant transaction may have.  12

Addonizio Direct / 10 II. A SSERTED BENEFITS OF THE ACQUISITION  1 
Q. What topics do you address in this section of your testimony?  2 
A. In this section, I describe and assess the two public interest benefits of the Acquisition 3 
claimed by the Petitioners: improved access to capital and access to the Partners ’ 4

 7 
A. OVERVIEW OF UTILITY FINANCING  8 
Q. Please generally describe utilities’ need for access to capital.  9 
A. As described in the direct testimony of Minnesota Power witness es J ohn D. 10 
Quackenbush  and Joshua D. Taran , electric utilities are capital -intensive businesses.  The 11 
provision of safe and reliable utility service requires significant amounts of long -lived 12 
physical infrastructure. T ransmission lines, for example  are often expected to remain in 13 
service for 60 years or longer, and wind turbines are often assumed to have 25 -35 year 14 
operating lives.  15 
  Ut ilities recover the costs of these assets from ratepayers over the  assets’  16 
operating, or useful, lives, rather than upfront. Because utilities cannot  fund new capital 17 
projects with funds provided by ratepayers, they must obtain the needed capital from a 18 
different source : debt and equity investors, via the capital markets.  Funds sourced from 19 
capital markets bridge the gap between when utilities need capital to pay for a new 20 
project, and when ratepayers pay for the project.  21 
 22 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT -  
HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL  
TRADE SECRET INFORMATION REDACTED
 
 
Addonizio Direct / 11 Q. P lease explain the general concept of a “rate of return.”  1 
A. Investors will not supply capital to a utility if they expect only to recoup their initial 2 
investments, and nothing more. Even if investors knew with certainty they would 3 
recoup their initial investments over time, investing their available cash in a utility (or 4 
any company ) would mean forgoing or delaying spending on consumption of other 5 
goods and services. Investors would require compensation for that forgone 6 
consumption. Of course,  no business is guaranteed to succeed, meaning utility investors 7 
may not recoup their initial investments.  Investors also demand compensation for that 8 
risk. Th e total  compensation  investors require in order to be willing to provide funds to 9 
the company is the required rate of return.  10 
 11 
Q. Are there important differences between r ate-regulated utilities  and non -regulated 12 
firms operating in competitive environments ? 13 
A. Yes. I n a competitive environment, prices, incomes, and rates of return are determined 14 
by the forces of supply and demand. For example, if one widget producer raises its 15 
prices too much, its customers can easily switch to a different widget producer with 16 
lower prices; competition keeps prices in check. Further, if there are not enough widget 17 
producers to meet aggregate demand for widgets, widget producers will have the 18 
power to raise prices and earn returns that are disproportional to the risks involved in 19 
widget- making – that is to say, the industry as a whole will earn returns greater than the 20 
rate of return investors require to invest. This high profit level will give entrepreneurs an 21 
incentive to enter the widget business. When they do, the total supply of widgets in the 22 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT -  
HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL  
TRADE SECRET INFORMATION REDACTED
 
 
Addonizio Direct / 12 market will increase, causing prices to fall, and the industry’s overall rate of return will 1 
decrease to the rate investors require. At that point, entrepreneurs will have no more 2 
incentive to enter the industry, and the industry’s rate of return will stabilize.   3 
  Similarly,  if the supply of widgets exceeds demand, the industry as a whole will 4 
not earn high enough returns to adequately compensate investors for the risks they are 5 
taking on. Some widget producers will go out of business, reducing total supply to an 6 
optimal level and widget prices will increase until the industry’s overall rate of return 7 
reaches the rate investors require. At that point, no one will have incentives to enter the 8 
industry, and again, the industry’s rate of return rate will stabilize at the rate investors 9 
require.   10 
  In s hort, in a competitive market, the forces of supply and demand interact in 11 
such a way that resources are allocated to produce an optimal mix of goods and 12 
services , and in doing so, push the rates of return actually earned by firms to investor’s 13 
required rates of return. This outcome is said to be economically efficient.   14 
 15 
Q. What are the differences for rate- r egulated utilities?  16 
A. For public utilities, the conditions necessary for competition to yield an efficient 17 
outcome are not met. Customers of a regulated utility do not have a choice regarding 18 
their utility service providers and cannot easily change providers in response to price 19 
increases the way that widget consumers can. Rather, utility customers are captive to 20 
the single electric or gas utility providing service where they are located. Similarly, due 21 
to the high fixed costs necessary to operate a utility, new utilities cannot easily enter the 22 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT -  
HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL

Addonizio Direct / 13 industry if profit levels are attractively high. For these reasons, utilities are often called 1 
natural monopolies. In fact, in Minnesota, electric utilities are assigned defined service 2 
territories and are given the exclusive right to serve customers in those territories; a 3 
competitor could not try to steal an incumbent’s customers even if it wanted to.  4 
  Abs ent some other form of intervention, utilities could exploit the monopoly 5 
power this lack of competition gives them, charge unreasonably high prices, and 6 
generate profits in excess of what competition would otherwise allow. For utilities, 7 
regulatory agencies assume the role normally assumed by competition. This means that 8 
regulatory agencies  must set prices and rates of return that ensure public utilities 9 
provide an appropriate supply of satisfactory services at reasonable rates.  10 
  In  rate case proceedings, regulatory agencies generally attempt to set rates for 11 
utility service that reflect a reasonable estimate of the utility’s cost of service referred to 12 
as a “revenue requirement.”  A revenue requirement is the approximate amount of 13 
money that a utility needs to collect from customers to pay all costs of service including 14 
a reasonable return for its investors. It can be expressed using the following formula:     15 
 16 
 As shown in the formula, a revenue requirement includes a r easonable rate of return on 17 
the investors capital the utility has invested in its system (that is, the utility’s rate base).   18 
 19

Addonizio Direct / 14 A. G enerally, companies, including utilities,  fund their operations with short -term debt, 1 
long -term debt, and equity. Each type of financing has a different level of associated 2 
risk, and therefore , investors require a different rate of return for each. Short- term debt 3 
is the least risky for investors, and as a result has the lowest required rate of return.  4 
Equity is the riskiest and has the highest required rate of return. Long -term debt falls in 5 
between.    6 
  Th e overall required rate of return for a company is the average of the required 7 
rate of return for each of these financing sources, weighted by the amount of each 8 
financing type the utility uses, and is otherwise known as the weighted average cost of 9 
capital (WACC) , or just the “cost of capital .” Table 1 presents the components of the 10 
overall rate of return approved in Minnesota Power’s most recent rate case as an 11 
example.  12

Addonizio Direct / 15 Q. H ow do companies decide what mix of debt and equity to use in their capital 1 
structures?  2 
A. Capital structure decisions can be quite complex, as companies must consider several 3 
competing factors.  Interest and principal payments on debt are fixed, contractual 4 
obligations for the issuer, and are prioritized over payments to equity investors; equity 5 
investors are said to have only a residual claim on a company’s earnings. Due to this 6 
extra certainty for debt investors, the cost of debt capital is lower than the cost of 7 
equity capital. Further, interest payments on debt are tax deductible, meaning that debt 8 
has tax advantages that equity does not. For these reasons, debt might seem like a 9 
relatively more attractive option to a company raising capital.    10 
  Ho wever, as a company’s debt load grows, so do its fixed payment obligations. 11 
As the company’s fixed obligations grow, so does the risk that adverse circumstances 12 
will prevent the company from meeting those obligations. A failure to make a required 13 
interest or principal payment could potentially trigger a costly bankruptcy, which could 14 
result in a complete loss of value for equity investors, and significant losses for debt 15 
investors. Investors will be aware of these risks and will require higher and higher 16 
returns on both debt and equity as the proportion of debt financing increases.  As a 17 
result, there is a limit on the amount of  debt a company can have before the risks 18 
associated with an incremental increase in debt risk start to outweigh the benefits  of its 19 
lower cost and tax advantages .   20

HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL

Addonizio Direct / 16 Q. W hat are the important implications of these dynamics?  1 
A. There are two implications worth highlighting. First, these dynamics mean that a 2 
company’s cost of debt, cost of equity, and capital structure are not independent of 3 
each other, but rather are all interrelated. A change in a company’s capital structure will 4 
necessarily result in changes to both its cost of debt and its cost of equity.   5 
  Sec ond, these dynamics mean, at least theoretically, that there is an optimal 6 
capital structure for each company that minimizes its after- tax weighted average cost of 7 
capital. Generally, starting from a very low level of debt, the incremental risk added 8 
from increasing the proportion of debt in a company’s capital structure is small enough 9 
that the tax savings generated by the new debt more than offsets the increase in the 10 
costs of debt and equity that result from the increased risk. Past a certain point, 11 
however, the effect of the increased risk more than offsets the incremental tax savings, 12 
and the increasing debt causes more harm than benefit. Figure 3 below provides a basic 13 
illustration of this relationship.  14

Relationship Between Capital Structure and the Cost of Capital5 2 
 3 
  The  Total Capital Cost line represents the average of the Equity Cost and Debt 4 
Cost lines, weighted by the proportions of debt and equity in the capital structure. At a 5 
debt ratio of zero ( i.e., 100 percent equity), Total Capital Cost is equal to Equity cost, as 6 
shown where the lines meet the y -axis.  Starting from a debt ratio of zero, incremental 7 
debt additions reduce the total cost of capital at first, but there is a point (50 percent 8 
debt in this illustration) at which additional debt starts to cause the total cost of capital 9 
to rise.  Somewhat counter -intuitively, an increase in the proportion of debt a company 10 
uses will result in higher costs of debt and equity but could result in a lower after -tax 11 
weighted average cost of capital.   12

Addonizio Direct / 18 Q. A re there legitimate reasons why a company might choose a capital structure that 1 
does not minimize its cost of capital?  2 
A. Yes. For example, a company may choose to carry more equity than would be cost - 3 
minimizing in order to maintain flexibility to issue debt on short- notice to navigate 4 
unexpected downturns.  Alternatively, if a company knows it is going to need to issue a 5 
significant amount of debt in the future to fund significant, planned capital 6 
expenditures, it may allow its equity ratio to rise beforehand to prevent its debt ratio 7 
from getting too high when it actually issues the new debt.   8 
  Ho wever, even in these instances, cost -minimization should be an important 9 
consideration, and a starting point for determining a target capital structure from which 10 
adjustments for flexibility or other reasons are made. In his well -known textbook on 11 
utility cost of capital, Dr. Roger Morin states “utilities should strive for a capital structure 12 
that minimizes the composite capital cost, including taxes.”6 Dr. Morin also states “…it is 13 
the responsibility of the regulators to ensure that a utility’s capital structure should 14 
reflect a proper balance between investors’ interests and ratepayers’ interest, and 15 
should be cost minimizing.  …  It is also important that a reasonable safety margin 16 
against possible shifts in capital market conditions and investor risk attitudes be 17 
allowed.”7  18

Addonizio Direct / 32 Q. D o you agree with Mr. Taran’s concern that investors and analysts d o not give credit 1 
to long -term growth projections ? 2 
A. No. Harvard Law Professor Lucian A. Bebchuk  a ddressed this idea succinctly in a recent 3 
article:  4 
If investors were systematically underestimating long -te rm 5 
prospects, growth companies would tend to trade at 6 
discounted levels, enabling their investors to obtain higher 7 
returns over the long term. But the empirical evidence 8 
indicates that growth stocks actually tend to offer lower 9 
returns over the long term —and thus, if anything, tend to 10 
trade at elevated levels —compared with stocks whose 11 
valuations are grounded in current profitability.  12 
Amazon and Netflix vividly illustrate that when appropriate, 13 
investors will accept with considerable patience a corporate 14 
strategy of investing in the long term at the expense of no 15 
or little current profit. Over the past decade the stock prices 16 
of those companies appreciated steeply, rising more than 17 
20-fold and 10 -fold respectively, even though their growth - 18 
oriented strategies resulted in relatively small profits along 19 
the way.  20 
Of course, some corporate leaders may take the view that 21 
the market doesn’t adequately appreciate the long -term 22 
prospects of their companies and consequently underprices 23 
their stock. But such reactions may simply reflect the 24 
tendency of those individuals to overvalue or defend their 25 
own performance. Even if a stock market price disappoints 26 
a company’s leaders, it may in fact accurately reflect the 27 
company’s long -term prospects.34 28 
 Thus, contrary to Mr. Taran’s claim, investors do appropriately c onsider the value of 29 
future growth in determining how much they are willing to pay for a stock in the 30 
present , and in some situations,  will tolerate lower near term profits . 31 
 
34  Bebchuk Lucian A. Don’t Let the Short -Termism Bogeyman Scare You. Harvard Business Review Magazine , 
January -February 2021. Available at  https://hbr.org/2021/01/dont -let-the-short -termism -bogeyman -scare -you.

Q. Are there any other reasons why you do  not agree with Mr. Quackenbush’s and Mr. 2 
Taran’s concerns?  3 
A. Yes. If the  public equity market regularly allowed for the types of inefficiencies  Mr. 4 
Quackenbush and Mr. Taran expressed concern about, savvy investors would be able to 5 
take advantage by buying the affected stocks when the ir prices dip ped, earning excess 6 
returns as the stock  prices  rebounded. But investors rarely earn returns in excess of 7 
passive market benchmarks  like the S&P 500 I ndex, and a large majority of active 8 
investors underperform the larger market . S&P Global recently released a study 9 
showing that more than 90 percent actively managed U.S. equity funds have 10 
underperformed a passively managed benchmark, both over the past ten years and the 11 
past three  years.35 That is because stocks are nearly always priced efficiently, and in the 12 
unlikely event that one is not, such mispricings are so difficult to identify that it would 13 
not be reasonable for a company to limit its share issuances based on an assumption its 14 
stock is underpriced, because the company would probably be wrong.  15 
  Wi th respect to broader market  downturns  that affect many stocks , it may seem 16 
obvious in hindsight, after stock prices have recovered, that stock prices were too low.  17 
However, if it were clear that prices were too low during the downturn, investors would 18 
have started buying, driving prices upward sooner. If investors collectively cannot spot 19 
such mispricings, corporate finance managers likely cannot, either.  20

seized and prevented issuers from refinancing, or rolling their  debt over, creating a 5

to banks for the right to force the banks to provide cash on demand. If a company were 11 
unfortunate enough to be planning for a stock sale when such an event occurred, its 12 
credit facility should provide enough temporary liquidity to delay the sale until the 13 
capital markets recover.  And to the extent such a significant emergency event persisted, 14

Addonizio Direct / 36 functioning of the stock market causing a c o mpany’s stock price to fall is precisely the 1 
mechanism that ensures it retains access to equity capital.  2 
 3 
Q. Please explain.  4 
A. The stock market sets equity prices such that the expected return on buying a particular 5 
stock is equal to the return equity investors require, which is based on the riskiness of 6 
the stock. If a stock’s price was “too low,” the expected return on the stock would be 7 
higher than investors require, and investors would start to buy the stock. By buying the 8 
stock, they would drive its price up to the point where the expected return equals the 9 
required return. If a stock’s price start out “too high,” then the expected return of 10 
holding the stock will be lower than the required return, and investors would sell, 11 
driving the price down.  12 
  Similarly,  if the expected long -run earnings of a company decrease, but its stock 13 
price does not fall commensurately, the expected return on the stock would be too low 14 
for new investors to be willing to buy it and provide equity capital to the company. In 15 
that case, the company’s access to equity capital would be limited.  16

Addonizio Direct / 37 Q. P lease continue.  1 
A. If a stock’s price is equal to its fundamental value, then issuing new shares to fund 2 
quality projects with expected earnings comparable to the company’s current expected 3 
earnings should have no impact on the value of the company’s currently outstanding  4 
shares. But if a company’s stock price is truly below its fundamental, or intrinsic, value, 5 
issuing shares results in a transfer of wealth from the company’s existing shareholders 6 
to its new shareholders, as for a given amount of total equity capital, the new 7 
shareholders acquire more shares than they would if the stock was priced “correctly.” 8 
This gives the new shareholders a larger percentage claim on the company’s future 9 
earnings than they would otherwise get at the expense of the claims of existing 10 
shareholders.  11 
  If  a company’s stock is priced below its fundamental value, new investors would 12 
be eager to provide new equity capital. But the board of directors and company 13 
management represent existing shareholders, not potential future shareholders , and 14 
would likely be reluctant to issue new equity because of the harm, or loss of wealth, 15 
that would be incurred by existing shareholders.  The company would likely be able to 16 
access the capital needed to fund its planned projects,  but management may choose 17 
not to do so to protect the interests of existing shareholders.  However, as described 18 
above, when corporate managers think their company’s stock price is too low, they are 19 
probably wrong.   20

Addonizio Direct / 53 Q. D o you agree that Minnesota Power’s cost of capital will not change as a result of the 1 
proposed Acquisition?  2 
A. N o. I do not agree with Mr. Quackenbush’s assertion that private eq uity investors seek 3 
the same investment attributes as public equity investors. Private equity investors 4 
generally seek higher investment returns than public equity investors and try to achieve 5 
those higher returns by taking a more active role in the management of the companies 6 
they invest in and implementing changes in the financial structure and operations 7 
intended to increase returns to equity investors.  Some of the  strategies private equity 8 
investors employ to increase investment returns , for example a significant increase in 9 
the amount of debt financing, may  raise the cost of capital of the companies they invest 10 
in. If the Partners were to use similar strategies to increase the returns they earn from 11 
their investments in Alloy (and, indirectly, ALLETE and Minnesota Power), it would likely 12 
increase Minnesota Power’s cost of capital, and result in rates for utility service that are 13 
higher than they otherwise would have been.  14 
  B ec ause of the nature of how the required return on equity is estimated in utility 15 
rate cases, the Commission will likely be able to mitigate the effects of potential 16 
increases in Minnesota Power’s cost of equity, but potential increases to the Company’s 17 
cost of debt will be much harder to identify, measure, and adjust for. For this reason, I 18 
agree  with  Ms. Bulkley’s conclusion that the methods the Commission has historically 19 
relied on to determine Minnesota Power’s authorized return on equity will still be 20 
reasonable to use post- Acquisition. However, I do not agree with all of the reasoning 21 
she used to reach that conclusion.  22

Q. Generally, w ha t are the broad differences between private and public equity 5 
investments? 6 
A. Private equity investors often commit their capital to private equity funds for relatively 7 
long periods of time without the right  to exit their investments. The loss of control 8 
resulting from this inability to sell their private equity holdings, or illiquidity, creates 9 
extra risk for the investors, as they may be unable to access their capital if they need it. 10 
Private equity investors also usually pay significant fees to the fund managers they 11 
commit capital to – a commonly cited, representative example is two percent of the 12

Booth School of Business at the University of Chicago, Paul A. Gompers and Steven N. 2

Successful private equity investing relies on careful 4 
evaluation of investments, structuring the investments or 5 
deals, financial engineering, governance engineering and 6 
operational engine ering.  Each of these activities creates 7 
value for private equity investors and their operating 8 
companies.71 9 
 10 
Q. Wha t a re “financial engineering, governance engineering and operational 11 
engineering”?  12 
A. Financial engineering is the adjustment of a firm’s capital structure, or the percentages 13 
and types of equity and debt the firm finances itself with, to increase the total value of 14 
the firm. Interest payments on debt are tax deductible, so replacing equity with debt 15 
creates tax savings (via the deductibility of the incremental interest expense on the new 16 
debt) that may increase profits for equity holders.72 Increased use of debt is also 17 
thought to impose discipline on company management by creating fixed payment 18 
obligations (higher interest payments) that prevent management from engaging in 19 
wasteful, value -destroying activities, although I do not believe this aspect of financial 20 
engineering applies to regulated utilities as strongly as it does to non -regulated firms.  21

Q. How might financial engineering increase Minnesota Power’s cost of capital?  7 
A. Alloy  wi ll own no assets or investments  other than ALLETE , meaning that all of the 8 
incremental interest and principal payments on debt issued by Alloy  or ALLETE 9 
(“incremental debt”) will ultimately need to be paid for by cash flows generated by 10 
ALLETE (and primarily Minnesota Power, which currently represent s roughly 70 percent 11 
of ALLETE).88 Any financial pressure or distress created by  incremental leverage  not 12 
associated with one of ALLETE’s other lines of business  will put pressure on Minnesota 13 
Power . If the incremental debt load becomes too large, or interest rates rise such that 14 
Alloy  or ALLETE  has trouble refinancing  the extra  debt  when it expires , Alloy  may try to 15 
extract cash from Minnesota Power  to pay the incremental debt  down .   16 
  Whi le the Partners  would be  limited in how they can extract cash from ALLETE 17 
(e.g., they cannot sell assets or issue large amounts of debt without prior Commission 18 
approval), they  can direct ALLETE to increase an incremental amount of debt in its 19 
regulated capital structure  within the range allowed by the Commission, cut 20 
maintenance budgets , or forgo capital expenditures and use the proceeds or savings  to 21

  Pre cisely for these types of reasons, the credit ratings agencies, when 4

methodology documents, S&P Global Ratings states:  7 
The determination of [stand -alo ne credit profile] includes ongoing 8 
interaction or influence, whether beneficial (positive), neutral, or 9 
burdensome (negative) … We consider that groups, including 10 
owners and affiliates, influence the [stand -alone credit profile]  11 
when there are regular interactions with the issuer.89 12 
  S&P  cites double leverage ( i.e., when a parent entity issues debt and invests the 13 
proceeds of that debt as equity in a subsidiary), higher shareholder distribution policies, 14 
and aggressive financial expectations from owners as examples of negative influences 15 
on a company’s stand -alone credit profile (and on its actual credit rating).  16 
  R ing-fe ncing measures do not eliminate these risks.   17
