Addonizio Direct / 73 Q. If  in a future rate case the Commission were to conclude that Minnesota Power’s cost 1 
of debt were unreasonably high as a result of effects of the Acquisition, would it be 2 
easy to calculate an adjustment to Minnesota Power’s cost of debt to remove those 3 
effects? 4 
A. It would be possible, but it might not be simple. In calculating Minnesota Power’s 5 
weighted average cost of debt, the interest rate on any piece of debt the Commission 6 
determines is unreasonably high could be replaced with a representative interest rate 7 
based on debt issuances from around the same time but from utilities with higher debt 8 
ratings. The Department does not currently have access to data that would easily allow 9 
it to conduct that type of analysis.  10

Q. Could Minnesota Power’s cost of equity also increase as a result of the Acquisition?  12 
A. Theoretically, yes. However, for practical reasons related to how the cost of equity is 13 
estimated, an increase in the cost of equity is less of a concern with respect to future 14 
rate proceedings.  15 
 16 
Q. What are those practical reasons?  17 
A. As described above, a utility’s  c ost of debt is usually calculated as the weighted average 18 
interest rate on its outstanding debt.  When a utility issues debt, the interest rate on the 19 
debt is determined by investors, directly observable, and readily available. While some 20 
may argue that the interest rate on a debt issuance is unreasonably high, there is little 21 
to no room to argue that cost of the debt is something other than the  actual interest 22

Addonizio Direct / 74 rate.  I f Minnesota Power’s cost of debt were to rise as a result of the Acquisition, it will 1 
automatically be reflected in the Company’s rates unless an explicit adjustment is made.  2 
  Th e is no directly observable measure  of the cost of equity comparable to the 3 
interest rate on a debt issuance . Instead , the cost of equity must be estimated with 4 
financial models applied to proxy groups of other utilities thought to be of comparable 5 
risk. A modeler has a greater degree of control over the inputs to a cost of equity 6 
analysis than he or she would with a cost of debt analysis, which typically begins with 7 
the utility’s actual cost of debt.  Thus, while the Company’s “real- world” cost of equity 8 
(i.e., the return investors would require in order to be willing to make an equity 9 
investment), the authorized return on equity that gets reflected in Minnesota Power’s 10 
rates will only rise as a result of the Acquisition if the return on equity witnesses model 11 
it differently. I generally agree with Ms. Bulkley that it would be unreasonable to do so 12 
as that would amount to rewarding the new shareholders for an unnecessary decision 13 
to raise the Company’s costs.  14

Addonizio Direct / 76 Commissions.  The Petitioners stated that bo th state commissions have the authority to 1 
protect captive customers against inappropriate cross -subsidization for the benefit of 2 
unregulated affiliates. In other words, the Petitioners stated that FERC did not need to 3 
consider cross -subsidization issues in rendering its decision on the Acquisition because it 4 
could rely on  the Commission and PSCW  to protect ALLETE’s captive ratepayers from 5 
related harms.  6 
  FE RC agreed with the Petitioners, but, consistent with established FERC Policy, 7 
required the Petitioners to submit an informational filing within 10 days of the 8 
Commission’s and PSCW’s action on the Acquisition. Thus, the Commission’s 9 
determinations regarding affiliate interest issues in this proceeding will play an 10 
important role in FERC’s ultimate decision on the Acquisition.  11 
  Ms.  Vavro discusses concerns related to the Petitioners’ plan to comply with 12 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.48 (2024), which governs utilities’ relationships with affiliates.  13 
 14 
Q. How will the Acquisition i mpact the Company 's ability to comply with Minnesota’s 15 
carbon -free standard ? 16 
A. It is not possible to predict with any specificity how the Acquisition will impact the 17 
Company’s ability to comply. The Partners’ desire and ability to invest capital in the 18 
Company will likely be one of the largest, if not the largest, determining factors. I 19 
discussed my related concerns above.  In addition, it is possible that both GIP and CPP 20 
Investments will sell Alloy and ALLETE prior to 2040, perhaps by several years. In that 21 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT -  
HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL  
TRADE SECRET INFORMATION REDACTED
 
 
Addonizio Direct / 77 case, the willingness and ability by the new owner or owners will play in important role, 1 
as well.  2 
 3 
V. CONCLUSION  4 
Q. Please summarize your conclusions.  5 
A. Based on the analysis described above, I conclude that:  6 
• The Acquisition is unlikely to provide Minnesota Power with meaningfully improved 7 
access to capital, and there is at least some potential that the Acquisition will worsen 8 
the Company’s access to capital.   9 
• Access to the P artners’ expertise resulting from the Acquisition is unlikely to provide 10 
any meaningful benefits to Minnesota Power’s ratepayers or the public interest 11 
generally.  12 
• If the Partners employ financial engineering strategies to increase the returns they 13 
earn from their investments in Alloy, the extra debt may cause Minnesota Power’s 14 
cost of capital to rise, which would result in rates that are higher than they otherwise 15 
would have been absent the Acquisition.  16 
• Ultimately, the Acquisition should not be expected to provide any meaningful benefits 17 
to ratepayers or the public interest, and poses several significant risks, as discussed 18 
above and by Ms. Vavro. Therefore, the Acquisition does not pass the Commission’s 19 
balancing test, as the potential detriments outweigh the potential benefits.   20

Topic:  “Reliability” of public capital markets  
Reference(s):  Petition at 16  
Request:  
 
On page 16 of the Petition, the Company suggested that the Partners will “provide more readily available capital than can be accessed reliably in the public markets .”  
a. Does ALLETE  admit that the rate of return it agreed to in Minnesota Power’s currently pending rate case is 
sufficient to provide ALLETE  with access to capital it needs to continue and expand its investment in clean 
energy technology and systems?  If not, explain your answer and provide all documents that support your answer.  
b. Please explain specifically what the Company means by “more reliably” in this context.  
c. Please identify and fully describe specific instances in the past when the Company was unable to raise 
needed equity capital from the public market due to a lack of “ reliability ,” and how the Company’s 
ratepayers and other stakeholders were negatively impacted.  
Response:  
 
a. Minnesota Power believes the rate of return in the pending rate case is reasonable based on the  agreement 
by all parties to the settlement agreement in that case. However, it does not change the nature of the public markets, the Company’s size relative to the industry, ALLETE’s unique risk based on its industrial exposure, nor the nature of the Company’s capital needs.   
 
b.  The reference to “more reliably” is in contrast to the volatility of the stock market that could make the 
cost of capital high during a down economic cycle and low stock price. GIP and CPPIB are proposing to

Topic:  “Flexibility” of capital sources  
Reference(s):  Petition  at 2 and  6   
Request:  
On pag
e 2 of the Petition, the Company referenced the “inflexible demands of the capital marketplace” and o n 
page  6 of the Petition  suggested that the Partners will provide  access to “flexible” capital.   
a.Please explain specifically what the Company means by “ flexible ” in this context, how the public capital
market is “inflexible,” and in what sense the capital the Partners will provide is expected to be “flexible.”
b.Please identify and fully describe specific instances in the past when the Company faced difficulties
related to the relative lack of “flexibility” of the public equity markets, and how ratepayers and other
stakeholders were negatively impacted.
Response:  
a.As previously discussed in response to DOC  IR 0014, 0015 and 0018, ALLETE’s capital needs  for the
future are larger relative to its size than any other utility. This places ALLETE  in a unique position where 
its reliance on equity financing through secondary offerings  (i.e., issuing additional stock) can have a 
significant effect on the Company’s financial  outlook.  First , relying on public capital markets exposes
ALLETE to the volatility of  the stock market. Over  the last two years, the AL LETE stock price has traded 
below $48/share and above $67/share , representing a 40  percent  variation over this period  (and
ALLETE’s stock trades at a discount to its peers because of several unique  characteristics of the
Company discussed in the responses to DOC  IR 0014, 0015, and 0018). As  discussed in our response to 
part (b), below, having to issue stock through a secondary offering when our stock price is low has a
material effect on the Company’s financial  outlook, which means the Company has less flexibil ity in
terms of timing of and access  to capital.  Publicly traded  utility stocks are valued on consistency of

earnings and dividends.  As noted in the Petition, the Partners have an ability to exercise more patience 
with respect to quarterly earnings and dividends due to their longer -term focus. In this context, (1)  
being able to raise equity as needed through the Partners versus taking what equity financing can be 
available in the public markets through  large secondary offerings that take an enormous amount of 
time and resources ; and (2) the Partners’  statement around being able  to exercise patience around 
short -term earnings and dividends are examples of   how the proposed Acquisition will provide ALLETE  
access to  “flexible” capital that can more readily meet ALLETE’s long -term and short -term needs 
without the quarter -by-quarter, year -by-year demands of public markets. To be clear, ALLETE will not 
lose access to the large institutional investors active in public markets, but will ins tead add to  the 
existing base of available investors through the Partners’ relationships with banking institutions and other investors and i mprove ALLETE’s flexibility in accessing capital.  
 
b. Issuing equity while  the stock price is low increases the dilution impacts and raises the cost of capital. 
ALLETE has managed this well in the past , but, due to the capital requirements going forward , the 
Company  would not have the ability to manage the timing of issuances without materially impacting 
the timing and efficiency around the execution of the strategy.  Specifically, due to the substantially 
larger annual requirements for additional equity that the Company will face going forward, the 
Company’s prior success in timing its  secondary issuances does not indicate that the Company will have 
the same success  going forward. Rather, the Company is far more likely to require substantial external  
equity during tim es of severe equity market conditions , resulting in a higher cost of capital.  Having the 
capital available  from the Partners will significantly mitigate these timing  issues that can materially  
impact the Company.

By Kenneth N. Gilpin
Nov. 11, 1998

VIEW ON TIMESMACHINE
TimesMachine is an exclusive beneﬁt for home delivery and digital subscribers.
Stocks slipped again yesterday, as sellers emerged late in the day to push prices
down for a second straight session.
Traders and analysts cited a variety of reasons for the selloff. There is continuing
concern about a slowdown in the growth of corporate earnings. Doubt persists that
the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee will cut interest rates at a meeting
next week. Renewed weakness in Asian markets, and heightened awareness that
hostilities may break out again in Iraq, increased the jitters. And after soaring for
eight straight sessions, the market apparently still needed a breather .
''This was a continuation of the consolidation that started on Monday,'' said
Marshall Acuff, an equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. ''Our market has
come a long way -- it got some support early in the session but then faded at the
end.''THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; Dow

The Dow Jones industrial average fell 33.98 points to close at 8,863.98. More than
679.7 million shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange, up from slightly
fewer than 600 million Monday.
Among broader market measures, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped
1.94 points, to 1,128.26. The Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks fell 1.57
points, to 396.86. But the Nasdaq composite index, aided by gains in several
Internet stocks and Intel, the big semiconductor manufacturer , rose by 4.57 points,
to 1,865.62.
The Dow was hurt by continued weakness in oil and financial company stocks.
Shares of J. P . Morgan & Company fell again yesterday, losing 2 1/2, to 97 5/8.
American Express slid 1 13/16, to 93 1/16.
Chevron and Exxon, also Dow components, weakened as well. Chevron lost 1 15/16
a share, to 80 1/2. Exxon fell 1 7/8, to 70 1/8.
DuPont, the nation's biggest chemical company, was the Dow's biggest loser . It fell
2 1/4, to 59 1/4, after BASF A.G., Europe's biggest chemical maker , said its business
in the third quarter fell short of expectations.
The declines in those stocks eclipsed strong performances from I.B.M. and
McDonald's, other Dow components. Riding a wave of optimism about computer
sales, I.B.M. shares hit an all-time high yesterday, rising 4 5/8, to 156. McDonald's
rose 4 1/8, to 7 13/16, after the company told analysts that sales are improving here
and abroad.
Technology shares were higher , helped by wild buying of Internet stocks. For the
second straight day, stocks in companies like Yahoo and Ebay rallied on
speculation that holiday shopping using the Internet will jump.

Yahoo shares rose 12 13/16, to 177 9/16. Amazon.com rose 4 7/8, to 131 3/4. And
Ebay, an on-line auctioneer that went public in mid-September at $18, gained 27 7/8
a share, to 130 7/8, after analysts at Goldman Sachs, the firm that led its initial
public offering, raised the target share price to $150.
''There is a lot of retail interest in the stocks, and some foreign money is going into
them, because we have been active in them,'' said Ed Collins, a trader at Daiwa

Optimism about the coming Christmas season also helped to push up Intel shares 1
9/16, to 97 9/16. After the market closed, the company said that fourth-quarter

Demand for Sprint Bonds
By Bloomberg News
The Sprint Capital Corporation sold $5 billion of bonds yesterday in the second-
biggest corporate sale ever , as investors rushed to take advantage of some of the
highest yields relative to benchmark Treasury securities in at least a decade.
The Sprint sale trails only the $6.1 billion issue by the rival MCI Worldcom Inc. in
early August. Worldcom, now the nation's second-largest long-distance phone
company, sold bonds to help pay for its purchase of the MCI Communications
Corporation.
Sprint Capital, a unit of the Sprint Corporation, the nation's third-largest long-
distance company, sold the bonds -- including a record $2.5 billion of 30-year debt --
as part of a plan to restructure the wireless venture Sprint PCS.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32, to 991 5/32. The bond's yield was
unchanged at 5.29 percent.

For the purposes of these requests, the “transaction” or “acquisition” refers to the transaction 
described in the petition dated July 19, 2024 and filed by the Petitioners in Minnesota Public Utilities 
Commission Docket No. E- 015/PA -24-198. The “ acquirers” refer collectively to Canada Pension Plan

 Request:  
 
 Reference Lapson Dir ect, 9:23:25:  You state: “Without adequate protection, the  utility ’s 
creditworthiness and access to debt capital could be impaired if its owner is in        financial distress, 
in default, or bankrupt. ”  Is it also true that the utility’ s access to equity capital can be impaired if its 
owner is in  financial distress, in default, or bankrupt ? 
 
Response:  
 
The initial premise of this question is flawed, as the likelihood of the new owners of the Company 
suffering from financial distress is unlikely. As explained by Witnesses Bram and Alley, the Partners 
are large, well -known, well -financed investment managers and the transaction is structured in s uch 
as a way as to insulate the Alloy entities from any financial impacts outside of ALLETE and 
Minnesota Power.  See also the response to CUB IR 0142.  
No. If the question refers to the financial distress of any of the Alloy entities, the proposed organizational structure makes them sufficiently remote from ALLETE and the utility that ALLETE 
(and by extension Minnesota Power) would retain access to short -term and long -term debt and the 
ability to issue preferred shares if additional equity is needed.

Response:  
  
See responses to DOC IR 0004 and DOC  IR 0005 above with respect to how GIP will raise and allocate capital to 
ALLETE as needed after the Acquisition closes.  CPP Investments’ capital comes from the funds not immediately 
needed by the Canada Pension Plan (“CPP”) to pay benefits to the CPP’s beneficiaries, which is received and 
managed by CPP Investments.  Such funds are allocated based on CPP Investments’ long -term investment goals, 
while ensuring that CPP Investments makes consistent investment decisions to mitigate risk.   
(1) Once fund raising for GIP Fund V closes, we do not expect any  new investors or capital will be sought for GIP 
Fund V.  GIP Fund V has a target of $25 billion, the majority of which has already been raised as of the date of this 
response and is sufficient to support the current and future investments in ALLETE.  Tower Bridge also has adequate 
capital for the acquisition. Once the fund raising for GIP Fund V closes, the fund will have a five -year investment 
period where it will consider making new investments, but in all cases Tower Bridge and GIP Fund V will retai n 
capital to invest in and support their existing investments, including ALLETE, for the life of the fund.  Accordingly, 
neither fund anticipates needing to seek new capital in connection with the ALLETE acquisition outside of each 
Partner’s respective fund commitments.  
(2) The GIP investment in ALLETE is a GIP Fund V investment, and no other GIP funds or investors outside of GIP Fund V and the investors in that fund will provide capital to ALLETE (except for the Tower Bridge fund and its investor, CalPERS, which is also an investor in ALLETE).  
(3) Yes, we expect the initial split of Alloy’s ownership (40% GIP Fund V, 20% Tower Bridge, and 40% CPP 
Investments) to be maintained as new capital is allocated to Alloy and ultimately ALLETE.  
(4)-(5) See responses to bullets (1) and (2), above, confirming we do not anticipate introducing new investors once 
GIP Fund V closes.  Accordingly, there will not be a need to balance interests of new investors or price new 
investment interests.

Response:  
 
This request appears to call for speculation, and neither ALLETE nor the Partners can necessarily identify all potential sour ces 
of debt or equity capital.  The following response is provided within that context:  
 
(a) Parent has received commitments for a $600 million term loan, only $300 million of which is expected to be drawn at close in connection with the acquisition, with the balance available to fund future capital projects of ALLETE, Inc. and its subsidiaries af ter the acquisition closes. Parent also has received a commitment for a $100 million revolving 
credit facility for use after the acquisition closes to assist in supporting future capital needs of ALLETE, Inc. and it s subsidiaries. The term loan and revolve r will be non -recourse with respect to ALLETE, Inc., its subsidiaries and their 
assets, as ALLETE, Inc. and its subsidiaries will not be obligors under such facilities. Additionally, ALLETE has a corporate revolving credit facility with banks, multiple bilateral credit or letter of credit facilities and various series 
of mortgage bonds and private placement notes.  
 
(b) Ongoing draws on funding committed to GIP V by its limited partner investors will remain available.  Please note that the five -year investment window relates to the decision to invest in new ventures and does not limit the 
provision of capital that has bee n committed prior to the five -year period ends. With respect to additional capit al 
for ALLETE, please see the responses to DOC IR 0007 and 0009.  
 
Once fund raising for GIP Fund V closes, new  investors or capital for GIP Fund V are not anticipated. GIP Fund V has 
a target of $25 billion, the majority of which has already been raised as of the date of this response and is sufficient 
to support the current and future investments in ALLETE. Tower  Bridge also has adequate capital for the acquisition. 
Once the fund raising for GIP Fund V closes, the fund will have a five -year investment period where it will consider 
making new investments, but in all cases  Tower Bridge and GIP Fund V will retain capital to invest in and support 
their existing investments, including ALLETE, for the life of the fund. Accordingly, neither fund anticipates needing

Request Number:  16 
Topic:  Benefits of Partners’ sector expertise 
Reference(s):  Petition at 1 7, Summary of Filing, 7- 8, and 16   
Request:  
 
On page 17 of the Petition, the Company stated that the Partners’ interest in ALLETE is not predicated on any changes to ALLETE or any changes to ALLETE’s operational practices.   However, in other parts of the Petition, the 
Company highlights the relevant sector expertise and relationships the Partners’ have and stated that Partners’ industry expertise will help support the Company’s infrastructure investment strategies and goals .  
a. Please describe in detail the relevant expertise and relationships possessed by the Partners that ALLETE does not already have.  
b. Please clarify how the Partners’ sector expertise will support the Company’s investment strategies and goals if not through improved operational practices.  
Response:  
 (a)-(b)  
The Partners are global leaders in the infrastructure space and have developed relationships and extensive 
experience from partnering with companies across the energy industry.  The Partners’ relationships and clean 
energy industry experience will assist the Company as it makes substantial investments in renewable energy, 
carbon -reduction, grid resiliency and reliability, and clean -energy enabling technologies in the years to come, in-
line with Minnesota’s clean energy policies.  For example, CPP Investments s uccessfully partnered with Puget Sound 
Energy (“Puget”), the largest electric and gas utility in Washington state with over 1.2 million customers, via a take -
private transaction in 2007.  This partnership similarly allowed Puget to execute its long -term gr owth strategy an d 
accelerate its decarbonization efforts. As noted in the Petition, as of March 31, 2024, CPP Investments managed 
assets totaling C$632.3 billion, with C$267.6 billion invested directly and indirectly in equity and fixed income in public and private companies across the United States economy, including in real estate, infrastructure, and energy.

Response:  
It is Minnesota Power's typical practice to avoid stating formal legal objections and/or standing on those 
objections to discovery in Minnesota regulatory proceedings, to the extent practicable, to facilitate a 
cooperative and productive process. However, many of the questions and stated premises, as well as the 
argumentative tone, in this set of information requests from CUB’s external witness (CUB IRs 1 -72) are 
outside typical discovery practices in the Minnesota regulatory process, and therefore necessar ily affect the 
Company's and Partners' responses.  
In a
ddition, consistent with Minnesota practice, the party(ies) and witness(es) responding to this discovery 
request are denoted by the witness information in the footer of this response.  
(a) and (b) Minnesota Power and the Partners cannot speculate as to counterfactual or hypotheticalscenarios regarding whether Puget Sound Energy’s efforts would have failed absent CPP Investments’ involvement.

b.There are many considerations that underlie the final corporate structure to support these types of
investments, the most significant of which is typically corporate tax considerations.  For this transaction,Alloy Topco LLC will serve as a “blocker” entit y for tax purposes.  A “blocker” entity is an intermediate
corporate entity that “blocks” the passthrough tax consequences that are normally associated with LLCs(i.e., as “pass -through” entities) by electing to be taxed as a corporation.  These entities s it multiple layers
above ALLETE and do not have an impact on the capital structure or rates of Minnesota Power.
c.Al
loy Holdings GP LLC will be owned by: (a) CPP Investment Board Private Holdings (6) Inc., (b) GIP Alloy
Aggregator, L.P. and (c) Tower Bridge Infrastructure Partners, L.P.
d.Al
loy Holdings GP LLC is a separate legal entity whose purpose is to manage and make investment decisions
on behalf of Alloy Holdings LP. The general partner of GIP Fund V and the general partner of Tower Bridgeare separate legal entities, distinct from o ne another and from the funds that they control.  The general
partner of each of GIP Fund V and Tower Bridge manage and make investment decisions for its fund entities.

Q. Are there significant potential risks of the proposed transaction related to regulatory 2

A. Yes. The Parties imply that Minnesota Power’s obligation to comply with the 4

Q. What are the Commission’s affiliated interest standards? 10 
A. I understand that Minn. Stat. § 216B.48 defines an affiliated interest with a public utility 11 
to mean every corporation and person owning or holding directly or indirectly five 12 
percent or more of the voting securities of such public utility. Under the statute, any 13 
contract greater than $50,000 between a public utility and one of its affiliated interests 14 
requires the written approval of the Commission. Companies also must file a list of their 15 
affiliated interests annually. 16 
   17 
Q. What is the purpose of these standards? 18 
A. Affiliated interest standards are designed to regulate and monitor business relationships 19 
between a public utility company and other entities closely connected to it. These 20 
standards are meant to ensure sufficient transparency around contracts between 21 
affiliated entities to prevent potential conflicts of interest. Without such protections, 22 
self-dealing could lead to inflated prices for goods or services or discretionary purchases 23 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT -  
HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL  
TRADE SECRET INFORMATION REDACTED 
 
 
Vavro Direct / 12 that are not truly needed, e.g., consulting services.  Minnesota regulations are not 1 
unique in this regard. Many states such as Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, Oregon, and Texas 2 
have statutes with very similar language, using the same threshold of five percent for 3 
defining affiliated interest. Other state commissions such as Maine and Virgina have 4 
statutes that are similarly constructed but have adopted a higher threshold of ten 5 
percent.  What these statutes all have in common, however, is that they provide a 6 
framework for the review of procurements involving affiliates to prevent favoritism 7 
and/or cross-subsidization at ratepayer expense. 8 
 9 
Q. How do these standards apply to the Partners?  10 
A. After closing, Alloy Parent, holding 100 percent of ALLETE’s voting securities, will quite 11 
clearly be an affiliated interest of Minnesota Power. As the owners of Alloy Parent, CPP 12 
Investments and GIP (now owned by BlackRock) will own 40 percent and 60 percent of 13 
ALLETE, respectively—clearly well above the statute’s five percent threshold. As such, 14 
any agreements between Minnesota Power and affiliates of GIP, BlackRock, or CPP 15 
Investments would require approval by the Commission.  Minnesota Power also will be 16 
required to file an annual report that identifies the full list of affiliated interests.  17

Q. How does the issue of transparency relate to the regulatory compact? 9 
A. Under the regulatory compact, utilities are required to provide safe and reliable service 10 
to ratepayers, and in return, they are entitled to recover the costs to provide that 11 
service, plus an opportunity to earn a reasonable return. The overall mission of the 12 
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission is to create and maintain a regulatory 13 
environment that ensures not only safe, reliable, and efficient utility services but also 14 
fair and reasonable rates. As such, one of the Commission’s primary tasks is to 15 
determine what constitutes a reasonable cost of service. Doing so requires the right to 16 
audit and proper access to books, records, and information from the utility and its 17 
parent. It also extends to affiliated companies to the extent their contracts are reflected 18 
in utility costs. 19

CORPORATE SEPARATENESS 7 
Q. What is corporate separateness?  8 
A. Ring-fencing is sometimes referred to as corporate separateness and is intended to 9 
create a virtual barrier that segregates a portion of a company’s financial assets from 10 
the rest. Ring-fencing measures are intended to insulate a regulated utility from the 11 
potentially riskier activities of an unregulated affiliate. A key component of the 12 
regulator’s side of the regulatory compact is ratepayer protections. Protecting the 13 
regulated utility from the threat of financial distress or bankruptcy is certainly part of 14 
that obligation. It also prevents the utility from being penalized with lower credit ratings 15 
because of its exposure risk, which can lead to higher debt costs reflected in rates.  16 
 17

potential business and financial risks associated with this transaction? 19

intended to generally hold ALLETE harmless from any business and financial risk 21

a utility that is not a discrete corporate entity would likely be very difficult without first 18 
adopting a holding company structure. ALLETE is clearly aware of this vulnerability and 19

Q. Please describe the current governance structure of ALLETE.  9 
A. ALLLETE has a traditional Board of Directors currently with ten members. All but the CEO 10 
are independent directors that meet the definition of independence under NYSE 11 
standards.30 The Board has standard committee charters in the areas of audit, executive 12 
compensation and human capital, and corporate governance and nominating.  ALLETE 13 
directors are recommended by the Corporate Governance and Nominating Committee 14 
and selected by the vote of shareholders. The fiduciary responsibilities of the ALLETE 15 
Board are spelled out, and the ALLETE Corporate Governance Guidelines provide for the 16 
nomination process, conflict of interest rules, independence of directors, and 17 
compliance with federal interlocking requirements.31 The current Board and its 18

Q. Please describe the overall purpose of a Board of Directors.  4 
A. A Board of Directors is responsible for managing the business and affairs of a 5 
corporation, and directors owe fiduciary duties to both the corporation and to the 6 
shareholders.   Well governed corporations have defined nominating processes for 7 
director selection with detailed standards for membership, voting procedures, and 8 
typically, shareholders vote for directors rather than simply appointing them.  9

A. The Parties have stated that Minnesota Power will not attempt to recover from its 2

The acquisition premium reflects a premium of approximately 19 percent per share 4 
relative to the closing price for ALLETE shares on December 4, 2023, the last trading day 5 
prior to when rumors of the proposed acquisition became public. The gain for individual 6 
shareholders, including ALLETE Board directors and senior management, depends on 7 
the purchase price of their stock. Transition costs incurred by ALLETE through 8

have not yet been incurred and would primarily include the cost of internal employee 12 
labor and related overhead. 13 
  Commitments for non-recovery of such costs are requisites for state regulatory 14 
approval of utility mergers, and they do protect ratepayers from potential future harm.  15 
To ensure proper exclusion from rates, however, adequate accounting methods for 16 
recording transaction and transition costs would be required to allow for transparency 17 
and future auditability.    18

reasonable efforts to maintain its debt/equity ratios and its corporate and facility ratings 20 
in accordance with regulatory requirements.44 This is not actually a commitment, rather 21

A. The Parties have committed to maintaining the current workforce and current 8 
compensation and benefits for a period of two years. They have also agreed to honor all 9 
existing collective bargaining agreements.45 Maintaining the status quo for two years is 10 
not a benefit, it is a short-term protection against future harm.  By way of comparison, 11

five years in its recent acquisitions of both South Jersey Industries and El Paso Electric.   13

potentially jeopardizing Minnesota Power’s reliability and service quality. 18

Vavro Direct / 31 VI. CONCLUSION  1 
Q. Please summarize your testimony.   2 
A. My principal conclusions are as follows: 3 
 The proposed transaction is inconsistent with the public interest and fails to 4 
meet the Commission’s approval standards under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50.  There 5 
are few, if any, positive benefits to ratepayers from this transaction, yet it 6 
poses significant risks that may negatively impact them.  7 
 Parties to this transaction have numerous and wide-ranging affiliations with 8 
companies in many industries. As such, the potential for conflicts of interest 9 
and cross-subsidization through affiliated interest contracts with Minneapolis 10 
Power is high. The Parties’ unwillingness to support the Commission’s due 11 
diligence efforts to protect ratepayer from associate harm, as set forth in 12 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.48, is particularly concerning.  13 
 The proposed governance structure fails to adequately balance the needs of 14 
shareholders, ratepayers, and the community, and there is a risk of outsized 15 
influence by the Partners on the day-to-day decision-making authority of 16 
Minnesota Power management.  17 
 Ring-fencing protections are inadequate, and do not sufficiently protect 18 
Minnesota Power from the effects of financial distress due to ALLETE’s non- 19 
regulated businesses.  20 
 In all, the regulatory commitments offered by the Parties offer insufficient 21 
protections to ratepayers and the public against future harms. 22

  Response:  
 
(a) CPP Investments objects to this request to the extent that it calls for legal analysis and/or legal 
conclusions.  
Subject to and without waiving the foregoing objections, please see the following response:  
Specific to this Acquisition, the Partners intend that “independent directors,” as described in the 
Merger Agreement and the Petition, refer to directors who are not employees or officers of ALLETE or the Partners.  
(b) Neither the members of the ALLETE Board following the Acquisition nor any process for 
changing the numbers of board members has been determined. As referenced in the Petition at Page 
11-12, upon closing of the Acquisition, the ALLETE Board will include  at minimum: (a) at least one 
member from Minnesota, (b) at least one member from Wisconsin, (c) at least two independent directors and (d) the chief executive officer of ALLETE.  
(c) Refer to (b) above.  Membership of the ALLETE board has not yet been determined but it is not 
anticipated that independent directors would have a quorum on the ALLETE board.  
(d) Refer to (b) above. CPP Investments notes that Superior Water, Light & Power, a Wisconsin utility, is a subsidiary of ALLETE, and independent Board membership from Wisconsin is a consideration.  
(e) Board authority is discussed in Section IV of the Direct Testimony of Company Witness Scissons. Refer also to SIERRA CLUB IR 0035.  
(f) Refer to (b) above.

0013.01 Attach SUPP 3 HCTS.   This document was prepared by GIP for its investment committee in May 2024 and 
was presented to the investment committee of GIP Fund V as part of its final decision to make an investment in 
ALLETE. The materials prepared for GIP’s investment committee are customary for any initial investment that GIP 
is considering making through its funds and include valuation information and highlight risks, challenges and 
opportunities related to a particular investment, including a range of potential outcomes, which are  based on 
assumptions the deal team professionals deem appropriate for a particular transaction. However, these materials 
represent and are based on projections, ranges of understanding, and scenario planning by GIP based on the 
information available at the time, in many cases predating the undertaking or completion of due di ligence. As 
such, the  projections are not certain, include outlier scenarios, and are not necessarily scenarios that GIP expects to 
happen. Once an investment decision has been made, th e materials and risks, projections and other analysis are 
not updated to reflect information that is learned subsequent to an investment  decision.   The content of these 
documents was prepared for limited purposes, may not reflect accurate or current facts or the current views of 
any party to the proposed acquisition, and may include discussion that is not necessarily relevant to the federal or 
state r egulatory processes.

ormation Request No. 32 
Re: 
 Lapson Direct Testimony, Section V, p. 17:  “The Partners are fiduciaries representing 
pensioners, pension funds, and institutional investors that seek stable long -term returns.”   
Expla
in how the governance commitments made by the Partners ensure that their fiduciary 
obligations will not conflict with the financial health or operational needs of ALLETE and 
Minnesota Power.  Provide examples of similar commitments in other transactions and their 
regulatory or credit rating outcomes.  
RESP
ONSE : 
The na
ture of this transaction reduces the likelihood of conflict between the best interests of the 
acquired utility and those of the new owners when compared with transactions in which the objective is to roll up a set of utilities and impose economies of  scale, cut staffing, and /or reduce 
local management.  This transaction seeks to preserve the Company as a separate entity with 
continuity of local management.  It is not in the long -term best interests of the Partners or their 
ultimate investors to take a ction in conflict with the financial health or operational needs of the 
Company and thereby reduce the Company’s long -term value.  Therefore, it is not clear that 
there is a conflict between the Partners’ fiduciary obligations to its investors and the long -term 
best interests of the Company.

The amo unt
 of future transaction costs is not known at this time, but the nature of those costs is expected to 
be similar to those incurred to date. As noted in the Petition, Minnesota Power is tracking these costs 
separately and will not attempt to recover these costs from its utility customers.  
The information herein designated as trade secret includes transaction costs and has been designated as 
nonpublic because it contains information the Company considers to be trade secret information as defined 
by Minn. Stat. § 13.37, subd. 1(b). This information derives independent economic value, actual or potential, 
from not being generally known to, and not being readily ascertainable by proper means by, other persons who can obtain value from its disclosure or use. Thus, the Company has made reasonable efforts to maintain its secrecy.   
(c)Transition costs have not yet been incurred and the amount of transition costs expected to be incurred in thefuture is unknown. Transition costs would not be incurred until the Acquisition receives all regulatory
approvals and closes. Transition costs, if  any, are anticipated to primarily consist of internal employee labor
and related overheads for employee time spent on transition activities. Such costs, if any, would be tracked
to ensure they are not included in utility customer rate requests absent Commission approval. As stated in
the Merger Agreement, the Company will not attempt to recover transition costs, if any, from its utility
